## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been experimenting with some commands in Verus, and I have a few questions. What type of information can I expect to receive when using the `listidentities` command?

**AI Assistant:**
When using the `listidentities` command, you can expect to receive a list of identities that match the specified filter. Each identity in the list will contain information such as the i-address of the ID, parent ID, identity name, content map, revocation authority, recovery authority, timelock, block height, transaction ID, status, and other permissions-related information. This command is super useful for getting an overview of your identities and their properties.

**User:**
That's really helpful, thanks! I've also been looking at the `recoveridentity` command. What is it used for in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
The `recoveridentity` command is used to recover a revoked identity in Verus. It takes a JSON identity as an argument, as well as several optional parameters that allow you to customize the recovery process. This command is essential if you need to recover an identity that has been revoked, perhaps due to a security breach or other issue.

**User:**
I see. So, what's the purpose of the `tokenrevoke` parameter in the `recoveridentity` command?

**AI Assistant:**
The `tokenrevoke` parameter is an optional boolean parameter in the `recoveridentity` command. If set to true, it will use the tokenized ID control token, if one exists, to revoke the identity during the recovery process. This adds an extra layer of security to the recovery process.

**User:**
Got it! And what about the `feeoffer` parameter? What's its purpose?

**AI Assistant:**
The `feeoffer` parameter is an optional parameter in the `recoveridentity` command that allows you to specify a non-standard fee amount to pay for the transaction. This can be useful if you want to prioritize the transaction or if you're operating in a high-fee environment. By specifying a custom fee, you can ensure that your transaction is processed quickly and efficiently.
What type of information can I expect to receive when using the `listidentities` command?

When using the `listidentities` command, you can expect to receive a list of identities that match the specified filter. Each identity in the list will contain information such as the i-address of the ID, parent ID, identity name, content map, revocation authority, recovery authority, timelock, block height, transaction ID, status, and other permissions-related information.

(text) i-address of the ID
   "parent": "xxxx",        (text) Parent ID of the chain the ID is on
   "name": "xxxx",         (text) The Identity Name
   "contentmap": {
   },
   "revocationauthority": "xxxx", (text) the i-address of the identity that can revoke this ID
   "recoveryauthority": "xxxx",  (text) the i-address of the identity that can recover this ID when revoked
   "timelock": 0          (integer) Timelock
  },
  "blockheight": n,         (integer) blockheight the current ID info was put on the chain
  "txid": "xxxx",          (string) Transaction ID at blockheight to put the current ID data on the chain
  "status": "xxxx",         (text) The revocation status ("Active"|"Revoked")
  "canspendfor": xxxx,       (boolean) Can the node running the command spend UTXOs on this ID (True|False)
  "cansignfor": xxxx,        (boolean) Can the node running the command sign for this ID (True|False)
 },
 ....
]
 ```
Examples:
```bash
> verus listidentities '{"name" : "myname"}'
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "listidentities", "params": ['{"name" : "myname"}'] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```
### `recoveridentity "jsonidentity" (returntx) (tokenrecover) (feeoffer) (sourceoffunds)`
#### Arguments:
```
    "returntx"            (bool,  optional) defaults to false and transaction is sent, if true, transaction is signed by this wallet and returned
    "tokenrevoke"           (bool,  optional) defaults to false, if true, the tokenized ID control token, if one exists, will be used to revoke
    "feeoffer"            (value, optional) non-standard fee amount to pay for the transaction
    "sourceoffunds"          (string, optional) tr
